text: Taiwan is home to TSMC, the world's top chip manufacturer, producing over 50% of the world's semiconductors and 90% of advanced chips.
Fengjia Night Market in Taichung is one of Taiwan's largest night markets, attracting thousands of visitors daily with its diverse food options.
Taiwan has over 100 peaks above 3,000 meters, including Yushan (Jade Mountain) which is the highest peak in Northeast Asia at 3,952 meters.
Taiwan was the first country in Asia to legalize same-sex marriage (2019), marking a historic moment for LGBTQ+ rights.
Bubble tea was invented in Taiwan in the 1980s, with Chun Shui Tang in Taichung being one of the first shops to popularize the drink.
EVA Air, Taiwan's major airline, has operated Hello Kitty-themed aircraft and airport lounges, showcasing Taiwan's embrace of kawaii culture.
The Tropic of Cancer runs through Taiwan, giving it a unique climate that supports both tropical and temperate species.
Taiwanese people celebrate Ghost Month in the 7th lunar month, with various rituals and offerings to honor ancestors.
Taroko Gorge is a spectacular marble canyon in Taiwan, featuring stunning cliffs, waterfalls, and the famous Eternal Spring Shrine.
7-Eleven stores in Taiwan offer various services including bill payments, package delivery, and ticket purchases, making them essential to daily life.
Taiwan was under Japanese rule for 50 years (1895–1945), leaving lasting cultural influences in architecture and cuisine.
Pineapple cakes are a popular Taiwanese pastry, with the word for pineapple (旺來 ong-lai) symbolizing prosperity in Taiwanese culture.
Taiwan's High Speed Rail system connects major cities at speeds up to 300 km/h, making it one of Asia's most efficient transportation networks.
Taiwan has thousands of temples, with many dedicated to various deities and serving as important community centers.
Betel nut chewing is a cultural phenomenon in some regions, with distinctive 'betel nut beauties' selling the nuts at roadside stands.
Taiwan's National Palace Museum houses one of the world's largest collections of Chinese artifacts, with hundreds of thousands of items.
Taiwan is a major producer of computer components, including motherboards, making it a crucial player in global tech manufacturing.
Taiwan has numerous hot springs, particularly in areas like Beitou and Wulai, making it a popular destination for hot spring tourism.
Taiwan's convenience stores offer various services including ticket purchases and package delivery, making them essential to daily life.
The Formosan black bear is Taiwan's largest land animal and a symbol of the island's unique wildlife.
The Dutch established their first settlement in Taiwan in 1624, building Fort Zeelandia in Tainan, which became their colonial headquarters.
The Spanish briefly colonized northern Taiwan from 1626 to 1642, establishing Fort San Salvador in present-day Keelung.
The Dutch introduced Christianity to Taiwan in the 17th century, establishing Protestant churches and introducing new agricultural techniques.
Taiwan's indigenous peoples speak Austronesian languages, making them linguistically related to people from Hawaii, New Zealand, and the Philippines.
The Amis tribe's harvest festival (Ilisin) is one of Taiwan's most important indigenous celebrations, featuring traditional singing and dancing.
The Bunun people are known for their unique 'eight-part harmony' singing style, which is recognized as an important cultural heritage.
During Ghost Month, Taiwanese people avoid swimming, whistling at night, and hanging clothes outside after dark, believing these actions might attract spirits.
